- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

1. Run an external program that produces an accent in its output.
2. Save the output to a variable.
3. Print the variable.

```
>> $result = python -c "print('à')"
>> echo $result
α
```

### Expected behavior

```console
The accent in a string should be retained.
```


### Actual behavior

```console
The accent was changed (`à` -> `α`).
```

comments.author: mklement0
comments.body:
PowerShell decodes output from external programs based on the encoding stored in `[Console]::OutputEncoding`, which defaults to the system locale's _OEM_ code page.

Python doesn't play by these rules and instead uses the system locale's _ANSI_ code page.

The solution is to (temporarily) set `[Console]::OutputEncoding` to that encoding, or, preferably, to UTF-8, along with requesting UTF-8 output from Python, using `-X utf8` (in earlier versions, set `$env:PYTHONUTF8=1` first):

```powershell
[Console]::OutputEncoding = [System.Text.Utf8Encoding]::new()
$result = python -X utf8 -c "print('à')"
$result
# You may want to restore the original [Console]::OutputEncoding value afterwards.
```

See also:

* https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/14945

title: PowerShell does not save accents correctly into variables
